page.title: 15BOROUGH FARM AND ROMAN VILLA
page.content: Borough Farm is largely grassland supporting a herd of 400 Suffolk Cross Mule sheep which are bred on the farm and sold for meat when they are between 3 and 6 months old. Buildings on the farm contain extensive "Pulborough" stone, probably quarried on the farm itself. Near the farm buildings and beneath grassland are the remains of a Roman Villa. First discovered in 1817,this was extensively excavated in 1910. The villa consisted of rooms and corridors opening off a quadrangle courtyard. Remains of a hypocaust were in one room; other finds included remnants of mosaic pavements, coins and pottery. Running from N. to S. on the eastern side of the farm is a bridlepath and footpath which mark the line of a Roman Road which linked Stane Street with an E. to W. road a mile to the S.
